an3.30:1.1: “These three kinds of people are found in the world.
an3.30:1.3: One with upside-down wisdom, one with wisdom on their lap, and one with wide wisdom.
an3.30:1.4: And who is the person with upside-down wisdom?
an3.30:1.5: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:1.6: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:1.7: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.8: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.9: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t stay.
an3.30:1.10: In the same way, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:1.11: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:1.12: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t pay attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, or end.
an3.30:1.13: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:1.14: This is called a person with upside-down wisdom.
an3.30:2.1: And who is the person with wisdom on their lap?
an3.30:2.2: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:2.3: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:2.4: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:2.5: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:2.6: It’s like a person who has different kinds of food crammed on their lap—
an3.30:2.7: such as sesame, rice, sweets, or jujube—
an3.30:2.8: so that if they get up from the seat without mindfulness, everything gets scattered.
an3.30:2.9: In the same way, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:2.10: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:2.11: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:2.12: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:2.13: This is called a person with wisdom on their lap.
an3.30:3.1: And who is the person with wide wisdom?
an3.30:3.2: It’s someone who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:3.3: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:3.4: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:3.5: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:3.6: It’s like when a pot full of water is set straight, so the water stays and doesn’t drain out.
an3.30:3.7: In the same way, someone often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.
an3.30:3.8: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an3.30:3.9: While sitting there, that person pays attention to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.
an3.30:3.10: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to pay attention to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.
an3.30:3.11: This is called a person with wide wisdom.
an3.30:3.12: These are the three kinds of people found in the world.
an3.30:6.1: The person with wisdom on their lap
an3.30:6.2: is better than that, it’s said;
an3.30:7.1: such a person can only learn
an3.30:7.4: but they’ve only grasped the phrasing,
an3.30:7.5: for when they get up their understanding fails,
an3.30:7.6: and what they’ve learned is lost.
an3.30:8.2: is better than that, it’s said;
an3.30:9.4: and when they’ve grasped the phrasing,
an3.30:10.1: they remember it with the best of intentions.
an3.30:10.3: practicing in line with the teaching,
an3.30:10.4: would make an end of suffering.”
